posts.title: Neil Gaiman Reads "A Christmas Carol" (Rebroadcast)
posts.text: We're celebrating the publication anniversary of the Dickens' classic with this special reading by Neil Gaiman from 2013.

posts.title: A Reporting Life in Latin America, Ep. 245
posts.text: Award-winning journalist delivered this year's annual Robert B. Silvers lecture, “Among the Drug Dealers, Criminals, Rapists: A Reporting Life in Latin America.”

posts.title: Magical Realism with Wayétu Moore, Ep. 244
posts.text: The debut novelist talks about Liberian history, storytelling, and her book "She Would Be King" with Buzzfeed's Isaac Fitzgerald.

posts.title: John McPhee's Album Quilt, Ep. 243
posts.text: The master of creative non-fiction writing shares his latest work and discusses the arc of his life and career with Paul Holdengräber.

posts.title: How Congress Really Works...or Doesn't, Ep. 242
posts.text: Comedian Wyatt Cenac moderated a conversation with Washington insiders and journalists from ProPublica and The Washington Post.

posts.title: James Baldwin's Children's Book, Ep. 241
posts.text: Did you know that when James Baldwin was writing "If Beale Street Could Talk" he was also writing a children's book?

posts.title: Susan Orlean's Ode to Libraries, Ep. 240
posts.text: Thirty years after a fire destroyed 400,000 books at the Los Angeles Public Library,  journalist Susan Orlean re-examines the tragedy in "The Library Book."

posts.title: A History of Voter Suppression with Carol Anderson, Ep. 239
posts.text: Dr. Carol Anderson is a historian and educator, and the author of "One Person, No Vote," a timely survey of how voting rights in this country have been rolled back, particularly for people of color, in the years since the 2013 Supreme Court ruling in Shelby v Holder.

posts.title: A Modern-day Gothic Horror Story, Ep. 238
posts.text: The bestselling author of "The Essex Serpent," Sarah Perry discusses her latest novel, "Melmouth."

posts.title: Making Movements Intersectional, Ep. 237
posts.text: Organizers, writers, and friends Darnell L. Moore and Charlene Carruthers share their recent work and discuss inclusivity within movements for Black lives.

posts.title: Why Men Fight with Thomas Page McBee, Ep. 236
posts.text: Reflections on masculinity, violence, and boxing from the first trans man to box in Madison Square Garden.

posts.title: Righteous Rage with Rebecca Traister, Ep. 235
posts.text: The journalist's new book traces the history of women's anger in America from the suffrage movement to #MeToo.

posts.title: The Secret Memoir of Bill Cunningham, Ep. 234
posts.text: "New Yorker" critic Hilton Als, and "Paper" magazine co-founder, Kim Hastreiter discuss the untold story of the New York photography legend.

posts.title: The Elite Charade of Changing the World, Ep. 233
posts.text: Journalist Anand Giridharadas asks whether the rich and powerful who have most benefitted from “our highly inequitable status quo” are in fact the best candidates to change it.

posts.title: Looking for the Real Lolita, Ep. 231
posts.text: An interview with author Sarah Weinman about the kidnapping of Sally Horner and Nabokov's novel that scandalized the world.

posts.title: Notes from the Reading Life: Tim Gunn and Min Jin Lee, Ep. 230
posts.text: The well-read fashion icon discusses some of his all-time favorite books with novelist Min Jin Lee.

posts.title: The Untold Story of the Up Stairs Lounge Fire, Ep. 229
posts.text: Making Gay History creator Eric Marcus interviews Robert Fieseler about his new book, "Tinderbox."

posts.title: Coming This Sunday: New Name, New Look
posts.text: Exciting news! Starting next episode, "The New York Public Library Podcast" will be renamed "Library Talks."

posts.title: There's No Such Thing As Now: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 228
posts.text: Why do we remember the past but not the future? Where do we locate the present? Is there such a thing as now? Italian theoretical physicist Carlo Rovelli discusses the true nature of time.

posts.title: Two Sisters' Path Toward Radical Islam: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 227
posts.text: Journalist Åsne Seierstad's latest book follows two teenage girls on their journey from Norway into Syria and jihad and their father's struggle to bring them home.

posts.title: Chronicling Illness with Porochista Khakpour and Eileen Myles: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 226
posts.text: Khakpour's new memoir sheds light on her experience as a writer struggling with Lyme disease.

posts.title: Love and Lanyards with Billy Collins: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 226
posts.text: A conversation with the former U.S. Poet Laureate and readings of some of his recent work.

posts.title: Literacy is a Human Right: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 225
posts.text: A special episode of The World in Words' live podcast recording at the Andrew Heiskell Braille and Talking Book Library.

posts.title: Roxane Gay and Aja Monet Tell Their Truth: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 224
posts.text: Roxane Gay's latest book, "Not That Bad: Dispatches from Rape Culture," is a collection of first-person essays that directly tackle rape, sexual assault and harassment

posts.title: Remembering to Listen with Arundhati Roy and Viet Thanh Nguyen: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 223
posts.text: Arundhati Roy and Viet Thanh Nguyen discussed Roy's life before she became a writer, the relationships between writing and political activism, plus Roy reads from her book The Ministry of Utmost Happiness.

posts.title: A Future for Democracy?: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 222
posts.text: New York Public Library President Anthony Marx brings together political analysts from the right and left to ask what the future holds for American democracy and for democracies around the world.

posts.title: Finding Hope on the Road in "Nomadland": The NYPL Podcast Ep. 221
posts.text: Journalist Jessica Bruder found that the best way to get to know her nomadic subjects was to join them.

posts.title: Tarrell Alvin McCraney & Donja R. Love Lift Up Black Queer Narratives: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 220
posts.text: The award-winning playwrights discussed Black joy, the legacy of queer writers, and the playwrights who have influenced their work.

posts.title: Sliding Off the Couch with George Saunders: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 219
posts.text: Last year's Man Booker Prize winner shares his thoughts on Buddhist philosophy, comedy, and a trip to the opera.

posts.title: The Harrowing History of Roosevelt Island: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 218
posts.text: Before there was Rikers Island, there was Blackwell's—today known as Roosevelt Island. Historian Stacy Horn's newest book Damnation Island: Poor, Sick, Mad, and Criminal in 19th-Century New York is the first in-depth look at its dark past.

posts.title: Kevin Young & Claudia Rankine Discuss "Brown": The NYPL Podcast Ep. 217
posts.text: Young reads selections from his new collection of poetry followed by a closer look at his childhood memories and his poetic technique with Claudia Rankine.

posts.title: Remembering Tom Wolfe and the Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test
posts.text: Wolfe’s legacy lives on at the New York Public Library; he was named a Library Lion in 1981 and the Library acquired his archives in 2013.

posts.title: Masha Gessen Explains Horror, Humor, and Hope for the Future: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 216
posts.text: Masha Gessen’s book "The Future is History: How Totalitarianism Reclaimed Russia" is the winner of the Library’s 2018 Helen Bernstein Book Award for Excellence in Journalism.

posts.title: Zora Neale Hurston's Story of the Last Slave Ship Survivor : The NYPL Podcast Ep. 215
posts.text: In 1860, more than fifty years after the transatlantic slave trade became illegal, a schooner named Clotilda docked on the Alabama shores. It carried in its hull the last known group of slaves to be brought to the United States. Among them was a man named Kossola, who became the last surviving member of the group.

posts.title: A Goddess Reimagined: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 214
posts.text: Madeline Miller's latest novel, Circe, puts you inside the life of the mythological goddess, one of the great characters of Homer's Odyssey. Miller discusses her writing process, witchcraft, and why this story resonates today with classicist and translator Emily Wilson, the first woman to translate The Odyssey into English.

posts.title: Trump's Doghouse has a Revolving Door: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 213
posts.text: Joshua Green discusses what it's like to interview the President, what actually motivates Steve Bannon, and how getting kicked out of the White House doesn't necessarily mean you're out for good.

posts.title: Why Net Neutrality Matters: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 212
posts.text: Library President Tony Marx convened a panel of experts to help shed light on the repeal of net neutrality. Where do things stand, and where do we go from here?

posts.title: Sheelah Kolhatkar has Inside Information: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 211
posts.text: Kolhatkar's book, Black Edge: Inside Information, Dirty Money, and the Quest to Bring Down the Most Wanted Man on Wall Street, tells the story of Steven A. Cohen and his involvement in the largest insider-trading scandal in U.S history.

posts.title: Isabella Rossellini Shares Her Eggs: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 210
posts.text: Actor and filmmaker Isabella Rossellini speaks with evolutionary biologist Menno Schilthuizen about animal behavior and her chickens.

posts.title: Building Movements with Keeanga-Yamahtta Taylor and Shaun King: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 209
posts.text: How have social justice movements evolved in the fifty years after Martin Luther King Jr.'s death?

posts.title: Reforming America's Prisons: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 208
posts.text: New York Public Library President Anthony Marx brings together criminal-justice-reform advocates from the right and left to discuss the complex issues of incarceration.

posts.title: Dr. John Carlos Has No Regrets: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 207
posts.text: Civil Rights leader and legendary athlete, Dr. John Carlos spoke with Dave Zirin, sports editor at The Nation and co-author of Carlos's memoir. Dr. Carlos shares his story of meeting Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the hardships he faced after the '68 Olympics, and the message he has for athletes continuing the movement for racial justice today.

posts.title: Debut novelist Akwaeke Emezi Recenters Reality: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 206
posts.text: Akwaeke Emezi discusses her debut novel, Freshwater, with Glory Edim, founder of the book club and digital platform Well-Read Black Girl.

posts.title: Michelle McNamara and Patton Oswalt's search for the Golden State Killer: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 205
posts.text: Comedian and actor Patton Oswalt shares the posthumous true-crime masterpiece written by his wife Michelle McNamara, who died suddenly at the age of 46 in 2016. McNamara, a true-crime reporter and creator of TrueCrimeDiary.com, spent years tracking the serial killer she dubbed the Golden State Killer.

posts.title: Confessions of a Nuclear War Planner: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 204
posts.text: Legendary whistle-blower, Daniel Ellsberg, discusses the military-industrial complex and the secrets he's been keeping for decades about the U.S. nuclear war program.

posts.title: Neel Mukherjee Tells Ghost Stories: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 203
posts.text: A conversation with the author about migration, home and his new novel "A State of Freedom."

posts.title: Tayari Jones Redefines American Marriage: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 202
Black Lives Matter Co-founder Patrisse Khan-Cullors: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 201
Networking with Niall Ferguson and Gillian Tett: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 200
posts.text: Historian and political commentator Niall Ferguson discusses his newest book with Gillian Tett, U.S. Managing Editor of the Financial Times.

posts.title: The Hunt for Timothy Leary: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 199
Jessica B. Harris & Carla Hall: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 198
posts.text: The James Beard Award–winning food historian and cookbook writer was at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture this past fall to talk about her memoir, My Soul Looks Back, with chef and co-host of ABC's The Chew, Carla Hall.

posts.title: Naomi Klein & Martin Breum: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 197
posts.text: Listen to a conversation about climate change and the Arctic between Canadian journalist and best-selling author Naomi Klein and Danish journalist Martin Breum.

posts.title: Masha Gessen and The Stories of a Life: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 196
posts.text: The journalist and National Book Award winner delivers in the annual Robert B. Silvers lecture an unexpectedly intimate account of her own biography, exploring themes of immigration, identity, and choice.

posts.title: Neil Gaiman Reads "A Christmas Carol" (Rebroadcast): The NYPL Podcast Ep. 195
posts.text: Gaiman's reading from 2013 uses a rare prompt copy that belonged to Charles Dickens himself and now resides in The New York Public Library. It was used for the express purpose of performing the story in front of an audience.

posts.title: Muhammad Yunus & Jeffrey Sachs: The NYPL Podcast Ep. 194
posts.text: Is self-interest the only force motivating business? Or can altruism be an equally powerful driver of innovation? Muhammad Yunus, Nobel Prize–winning father of microcredit, discussed these questions—the subject of his latest book—with fellow economist Jeffrey Sachs.

posts.title: Podcast #193: Nikki Giovanni & Joy-Ann Reid
posts.text: The titan of American poetry was at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in November to talk about her latest collection, A Good Cry. She spoke with Joy-Ann Reid, the host of MSNBC's AM Joy.

posts.title: Podcast #192: Stephen Greenblatt & Tony Kushner—The Rise and Fall of Adam and Eve
posts.text: Exploring the power of narrative to travel from myth into reality, Greenblatt and Kushner trace the tale from it's biblical origins through its imaginings in the minds of writers and artists from St. Augustine to Albrecht Dürer to John Milton.

posts.title: Podcast #191: Kevin Young & Bunk—Hoaxes, Hooey, Hocum; Cons, Plagiarists, and Forgers
posts.text: Kevin Young, the Director of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture and the Poetry Editor of The New Yorker,  traces the history of the hoax as a peculiarly American phenomenon in his most recent nonfiction book,  Bunk: The Rise of Hoaxes, Humbug, Plagiarists, Phonies, Post-Facts, and Fake News.

posts.title: Podcast #190: Anne Applebaum, Fighting Against the Great Forgetting
posts.text: The Pulitzer Prize–winning historian and Washington Post columnist on the true story behind one of Josef Stalin's greatest crimes, against the people of Ukraine, during the Soviet famine of the early 1930s.

posts.title: Podcast #189: Theaster Gates—"I'm Trying to Create an Intimate Moment with Our Most Treasured Assets."
posts.text: The future of archives with the Chicago-based artist, urban planner, and professor. This conversation was presented by the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture.

posts.title: Podcast #188: Van Jones: "You have to keep open the possibility for redemption."
posts.text: Few people manage to be simultaneously as outspoken and as civil as activist, CNN analyst, and author Van Jones. The complicated and admirable mix is on display on today's epsidode, in which Jones speaks with his CNN colleague Brooke Baldwin about his latest book, Beyond the Messy Truth: How We Came Apart; How We Come Together.

posts.title: Podcast #187: Ron Chernow—Grant
posts.text: The Pulitzer Prize– and National Book Award–winning historian says the legacy of the Civil War hero and 18th president is deeply misunderstood. He makes the case in his latest book, Grant, and in this conversation with Richard Stengel, former managing editor of TIME magazine.

posts.title: Podcast #186: Nasty Women
posts.text: The co-editors of the essay collection Nasty Women along with select contributors to it explore the complications of being an American woman in 2017. Featuring Kate Harding and Samhita Mukhopadhyay, with Kera Bolonik, Zerlina Maxwell, and Meredith Talusan. Moderated by Jezebel founder Anna Holmes.

posts.title: Podcast #185: Mike Wallace, Greater Gotham
posts.text: Twenty years in the making, Greater Gotham is Pulitzer Prize–winning historian Mike Wallace's follow-up to his 1999 Gotham. He spoke about the New York City history, which covers 1898 to 1918, with The New Yorker's Jelani Cobb.

posts.title: Podcast #184: Salman Rushdie, The Golden House
posts.text: The Booker Prize–winning novelist Salman Rushdie discusses his twelfth, and most recent, novel, The Golden House.

posts.title: Podcast #183: Jesmyn Ward—Sing, Unburied, Sing
posts.text: The National Book Award–winning author spoke at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture about her most recent novel, Sing, Unburied, Sing. She was joined by Lisa Lucas, Executive Director of the National Book Foundation.

posts.title: Podcast #182: Atul Gawande & Elizabeth Alexander
posts.text: Two writers, two beautiful books, both on the subject of death. Atul Gawande's Being Mortal examines the lengths modern medicine must go to better humanize the final stages of our lives. Elizabeth Alexander's The Light of the World is the memoir of her husband Ficre's sudden and unexpected death, and Alexander's process of grieving and rebuilding that followed it.

posts.title: Podcast #181: Kurt Andersen, Fantasyland
posts.text: The host and co-creator of Studio 360 discusses his new book, Fantasyland: How American Went Haywire, with NYU professor Kwame Anthony Appiah.

posts.title: Podcast #180: Raoul Peck, "I Am Not Your Negro"
posts.text: The filmmaker speaks about his groundbreaking documentary "I Am Not Your Negro" at the Schomburg Center with the Schomburg's Director, Kevin Young and LIVE from the NYPl's Paul Holdengräber.

posts.title: Podcast #179: Ayobami Adebayo—Stay With Me
posts.text: The Nigerian writer discusses her debut novel, Stay With Me, the haunting tale of a young couple whose childless marriage threatens to tear them apart. It was shortlisted for the Baileys Women's Prize for Fiction and hailed by Michiko Kakutani as "powerfully magnetic and heartbreaking."

posts.title: Podcast #178: Ibram X. Kendi, Stamped from the Beginning
posts.text: Kendi discussed his National Book Award–winning work on the history of racist ideas in America with Khalil Gibran Muhammad, the Director Emeritus of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture.

posts.title: Podcast #177: Noam Chomsky and Wallace Shawn
posts.text: MIT linguist, philosopher, and political theorist Noam Chomsky speaks with actor and playwright Wallace Shawn, diving behind the headlines in an attempt to rigorously and rationally think through the political complications of American life today.

posts.title: Podcast #176: How Judy Collins Conquered Her Cravings
posts.text: Grammy-winning singer and songwriter and best-selling author Judy Collins talks about her latest book, Cravings, a memoir of Collins' lifelong struggle with an eating disorder—and the story of a search for a spiritual solution to her problems with food.

posts.title: Podcast #175: Lynn Nottage & Sweat
posts.text: The Pulitzer Prize–winning playwright was joined in May by members of the Broadway cast of Sweat to talk about the play and the issues behind it at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture.

posts.title: Podcast #174: Immigrant Stories—Min Jin Lee with Simon Winchester
posts.text: Best-selling novelist Min Jin Lee on her latest book, the ups and downs of her career, the history of Koreans in Japan, and the treatment of Asians in America.

posts.title: Podcast #173: Phillip Glass, Words Without Music
posts.text: The giant of twentieth-century American music took to the LIVE from the NYPL stage in June. He spoke with Paul Holdengräber.

posts.title: Podcast #172: Janet Mock, Surpassing Certainty
posts.text: Mock published her second memoir, "Surpassing Certainty" in June. The writer, activist, tv host, and podcast host came by the Library to talk about it with Lisa Lucas, the Executive Director of the National Book Foundation.

posts.title: Podcast #171: Nick Cave
posts.text: One of contemporary art's most towering figures guides us through his astonishing new exhibition at MASS MoCA.

posts.title: Podcast #170: David Grann
posts.text: In the 1920s, the Osage Indian nation in Oklahoma become oil millionaires after black gold was discovered under their land. Discover the stories of the mysterious that followed and one of the FBI's earliest investigations.

posts.title: Podcast #169: Tracy K. Smith, New U.S. Poet Laureate
posts.text: Smith was named 22nd U.S. Poet Laureate last week. In 2016 she came by the Library to discuss her memoir, Ordinary Light.

posts.title: Podcast #168: Jelani Cobb, The Half-Life of Freedom
posts.text: New Yorker staff writer and Columbia Journalism School professor Jelani Cobb delivers a lecture on politics, journalism, and history entitled "The Half-Life of Freedom."

posts.title: Podcast #167: Alec Baldwin
posts.text: Alec Baldwin spoke with NY Times critic-at-large Wesley Morris about his recent memoir, "Nevertheless," at LIVE from the NYPL.

posts.title: Podcast #166: Journalism in the Age of Trump, part 2
posts.text: This week's episode features a conversation between Katherine Boo, Anand Giridharadas, and Philip Gourevitch, who are all past winners of the Library’s Helen Bernstein Book Award for Excellence in Journalism. The three speakers picked up the conversation that we began back in February on the shifting responsibilities, purposes, and even definitions of journalism.

posts.title: Podcast #165: Jane Mayer, Winner of the 2017 Bernstein Award
posts.text: Is the Trump Administration a dream or a nightmare for the Koch brothers? Are cats more intrinsically valuable than people? Answering many questions about the intricate relationship between money and politics in American life with Jane Mayer, a New Yorker staff writer and author of Dark Money (2017 winner of NYPL's Bernstein Award).

posts.title: Podcast #164: George Packer and Reihan Salam with Tony Marx
posts.text: The Path Forward: Our Age of Anxiety. Explore both the seeds and the fruits of our present American political condition with New Yorker writer George Packer, National Review editor Reihan Salam, and New York Public Library President Tony Marx.

posts.title: Podcast #163: Janine di Giovanni, Bernstein Award Finalist
posts.text: Bernstein Award finalist Janine di Giovanni talks about her book, "The Morning They Came For Us: Dispatches from Syria," the story of Syria's civil war as told through the people who have lived through it.

posts.title: Podcast #162: Charlotte McDonald-Gibson, Bernstein Award Finalist
posts.text: Bernstein Award finalist Charlotte McDonald-Gibson talks about her book, 'Cast Away: True Stories of Survival from Europe's Refugee Crisis,' which follows individuals fleeing violence and persecution in Syria, Libya, Nigeria, and Eritrea.

posts.title: Podcast #161: Lawrence Krauss w/ Alan Alda. Reality, the Real Story
Podcast #160: Gary Younge, Bernstein Award Finalist
posts.text: Bernstein Award finalist Gary Younge talks about his book, Another Day in the Death of America, which charts gun violence fatalities among children and teens on one Saturday in 2013.

posts.title: Podcast# 159: Like Passover, But Funnier
posts.text: Comedians Dave Barry, Alan Zweibel, and Adam Mansbach share their new take on the Haggadah with comedian and NPR host Ophira Eisenberg. Their book is called "For This We Left Egypt?"

posts.title: Podcast #158: Sonia Shah & 'Pandemic,' Bernstein Award Finalist
posts.text: Sonia Shah's new book 'Pandemic' uses the history of cholera as a template toward understanding the life cycles of disease outbreaks and how our how our next global pandemic might arise.

posts.title: Podcast #157: Women's and Girls' Lives Matter
posts.text: An extraordinary group of women who are on the front lines of the fight for bettering the lives for young black women and girls across the country gathered at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture this International Women's Day to highlight the roles, needs, and contributions of black women and girls in the context of the Black Lives Matter Movement moment.

posts.title: Podcast #156: What Patients Say, What Doctors Hear with Dr. Ofri and Mary Harris
posts.text: Dr. Danielle Ofri speaks with WNYC host Mary Harris about her new book, What Patients Say, What Doctors Hear, which proves that medicine doesn’t have to work that way, and how better communication can lead to better health for all of us.

posts.title: Podcast #155: Etgar Keret, the Rock and the Hard Place
posts.text: For this week's episode of the New York Public Library Podcast, we're proud to present Israeli writer Etgar Keret in conversation with LIVE from the NYPL's own Paul Holdengraber.
